page.title: 08TREES AT POLWARTH 1
page.content: MANY FORMS OF TREE FLORISH. THERE ARE SEVERAL SOFTWOOD PLANTATIONS WHICH HAVE BEEN PLANTED AT INTERVALS, BUT THE MOST TYPICAL TREE IS THE BEECH WHICH GROWS TALL & STRAIGHT. ONE UNIQUE SPECIMEN IN THE LONG AVENUE AT MARCHMONT WAS USED FOR SEED BY A FORESTRY CONSULTANT WHO ACQUIRED THE BEECH MAST, THE TREE BEING TOO TALL & STRAIGHT TO CLIMB, BY SHOOTING IT DOWN. THE LONG AVENUE STRETCHES FOR 1.25 MILES IN FRONT OF MARCHMONT & IS A FINE EXAMPLE OF A BEECH AVENUE. IT WAS PLANTED IN 1740 BY THE SECOND EARL OF MARCHMONT, 10 YEARS BEFORE HIS SON, THE THIRD EARL, BUILT THE HOUSE. THERE IS ALSO THE REMAINS OF A CROSS AVENUE OF EVEN OLDER TREES, SOME SPANISH CHESTNUTS, WHICH LED TO THE 17 CENTURY HOUSE OF REDBRAES, BESIDE WHOSE RUINS IS A BOX HEDGE OVER 300 YEARS OLD & 20 FOOT HIGH & ALSO ANCIENT YEW TREES.
